titleStmt.title: Shakespeare, William: THE HISTORY OF HENRIE THE FOVRTH; With the battell at Shrewsburie, betweene the King and Lord Henry Percy, surnamed Henrie Hotspur of the North, With the humorous conceits of Sir Iohn Falstalffe.

respStmt.name: Kyonnah Price with homographing and regularising completed by Alexis Antonia

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by P.S. for Andrew Wise, dwelling in Paules Churchyard, at the signe of the Angell.

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following

div2.stage: Enter the King, Lord Iohn of Lancaster, Earle of Westmerland, with others.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: SO shaken as we are, so wan with care,
Find we a time for frighted peace to pant,
And breath short winded accents of new broils
To be commenced in strands afar remote:
No more the thirsty entrance of this soil
Shall daub her lips with her own children's blood,
No more shall trenching war channel her fields,
Nor bruise her flowerets with the armed hooves
Of hostile paces: those opposed eyes,
Which like the meteors of a troubled heaven,
All of one nature, of one substance bred,
Did lately meet in the intestine shock
And furious close of civil butchery,
Shall now in mutual well-beseeming ranks,
March all one way, and be no more opposed
Against acquaintance, kindred and allies.
The edge of war, like an ill sheathed knife,
No more shall cut his master: therefore friends,
As far as to the sepulchre of Christ,
Whose soldier now, under whose blessed cross
We are impressed and engaged to fight,
Forthwith a power of English shall we levy,
Whose arms were moulded in their mothers womb,
To chase these pagans in those holy fields,
Over whose acres walked those blessed feet,
Which 1400. years ago were nailed,
For our advantage on the bitter cross.
But this our purpose now is twelve month old,
And bootless it is to tell you we will go.
Therefore we meet not now: then let me hear
Of you my gentle Cousin Westmerland,
What yesternight our counsel did decree
In forwarding this dear expedience.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: My liege, this haste was hot in question,
And many limits of the charge set down
But yesternight, when all athwart there came
A post from Wales, laden with heavy news,
Whose worst was that the noble Mortimer,
Leading the men of Herdforshire to fight
Against the irregular, and wild Glendower,
Was by the rude hands of that Welshman taken,
A thousand of his people butchered,
Upon whose dead corpses there was such misuse,
Such beastly shameless transformation
By those Welsh-women done, as may not be
Without much shame, retold, or spoken of.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It seems then that the tidings of this broil,
Brake off our business for the holy land.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: This matched with other did, my gracious L.
For more uneven and unwelcome news
Came from the North, and thus it did import,
On holly rode day, the gallant Hotspur there,
Young Harry Percy, and brave Archibold,
That ever valiant and approved Scot,
At Holmedon met, where they did spend
A sad and bloody hour:
As by discharge of their artillery,
And shape of likelihood the news was told:
For he that brought them in the very heat
And pride of their contention, did take horse
Uncertain of the issue any way.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here is dear, a true industrious friend,
Sir Walter Blunt new lighted from his horse,
Stained with the variation of each soil,
Betwixt that Holmedon and this seat of ours:
And he hath brought us smooth and welcome news,
The Earl of Douglas is discomfited,
Ten thousand bold Scots, two and twenty knights
Balked in their own blood. Did sir Walter see
On Holmedons plains, of prisoners Hotspur took
Mordake Earl of Fife, and eldest son
To beaten Douglas, and the Earl of Athol,
Of Murrey, Angus, and Menteith:
And is not this an honourable spoil?
A gallant prize? Ha cousin, is it not?
In faith it is.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: A conquest for a Prince to boast of.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yea, there thou makest me sad, and makest me sin
In envy, that my Lord Northumberland
Should be the father to so blessed a son:
A son, who is the theme of honours tongue,
Amongst a grove, the very straightest plant,
Who is sweet fortunes minion and her pride,
Whilst I by looking on the praise of him
See riot and dishonour stain the brow
Of my young Harry. O that it could be proved
That some night tripping fairy had exchanged,
In cradle clothes our children where they lay,
And called mine Percy, his Plantagenet,
Then would I have his Harry, and he mine:
But let him from my thoughts. What think you coz
Of this young Percies pride? The prisoners
Which he in this adventure hath surprised
To his own use, he keeps and sends me word
I shall have none but Mordake Earl of Fife.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: This is his uncles teaching. This is Worcester,
Malevolent to you in all aspects,
Which makes him prune himself, and bristle up
The crest of youth against your dignity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But I have sent for him to answer this:
And for this cause a while we must neglect
Our holy purpose to Ierusalem.
Cousin on wednesday next our council we will hold
At Windsore, so inform the Lords:
But come yourself with speed to us again,
For more is to be said and to be done,
Than out of anger can be uttered.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: I will my liege.

div2.stage: Enter prince of Wales, and Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Now Hal, what time of day is it lad?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Thou art so fat-witted with drinking of old sack,
and unbuttoning thee after supper, and sleeping upon benches
after noon; that thou hast forgotten to demand that truly
which thou wouldest truly know. What a devil hast thou to
do with the time of the day? unless hours were cups of sack,
and minutes capons, and clocks the tongues of Bawds, and
Dials the signs of leaping houses, and the blessed sun
himself a fair hot wench in flame coloured taffeta; I see no
reason why thou shouldst be so superfluous to demand the
time of the day.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Indeed you come near me now Hal, for we that
take purses go by the moon and the seven stars, and not by
Phoebus, he, that wandering knight so fair: and I prithee sweet
wag when thou art a king, as God save thy grace: majesty I
should say, for grace thou wilt have none.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What none?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: No by my troth, not so much as will serve to be prologue to an egg and butter.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Well, how then? come roundly, roundly.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Marry then sweet wag, when thou art king let not us
that are squires of the nights body, be called thieves of the
days beauty: let us be Dianaes foresters, gentlemen of the
shade, minions of the moon, and let men say we be men of
good government, being governed as the sea is, by our noble
and chaste mistress the moon, under whose countenance
we steal.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Thou sayst well, and it holds well too, for the fortune
of us that are the moons men, doth ebb and flow like the sea,
being governed as the sea is by the moon, as for proof. Now
a purse of gold most resolutely snatched on Monday night and
most dissolutely spent on tuesday morning, got with swearing,
lay by, and spent with crying, bring in, now in as low an ebb
as the foot of the ladder, and by and by in as high a flow as the
ridge of the gallows.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
By the Lord thou sayst true lad, and is not my hostess
of the tavern a most sweet wench?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
As the honey of Hibla my old lad of the castle, and is
not a buff Jerkin a most sweet robe of durance?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
How now, how now mad wag, what in thy quips
and thy quiddities? what a plague have I to do with a buff
Jerkin?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Why what a pox have I to do with my hostess of
the tavern?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Well, thou hast called her to a reckoning many a time
and oft.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Did I ever call for thee to pay thy part?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: No, I will give thee thy due, thou hast paid all there.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Yea and else where, so far as my coin would stretch,
and where it would not, I have used my credit.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Yea, and so used it that were it not here apparent that
thou art heir apparent. But I prithee sweet wag, shall there be
gallows standing in England when thou art king? and resolution thus fubbed as it is with the rusty curb of old father Antic the law, do not thou when thou art king hang a thief.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: No, thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Shall I? O rare! by the Lord I will be a brave judge.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Thou judgest false already, I mean thou shalt have
the hanging of the thieves, and so become a rare hangman.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Well Hall well, and in some sort it jumps with my
humour, as well as waiting in the Court I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: For obtaining of suites?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Yea, for obtaining of suites, whereof the hangman
hath no lean wardrobe. 'sblood I am as melancholy as a gib
Cat, or a lugged bear.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Or an old lion, or a lovers Lute.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Yea, or the drone of a Lincolnshire bagpipe.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
What sayst thou to a Hare, or the melancholy of
Mooreditch?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Thou hast the most unsavoury smiles, and art indeed
the most comparative rascalliest sweet young Prince. But Hal,
I prithee trouble me no more with vanity, I would to God
thou and I knew where a commodity of good names were
to be bought: an old Lord of the council rated me the other day in the street about you sir, but I marked him not, and
yet he talked very wisely, but I regarded him not, and yet he
talked wisely and in the street too.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Thou didst well, for wisdom cries out in the streets
and no man regards it.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
O thou hast damnable iteration, and art indeed able
to corrupt a saint: thou hast done much harm upon me Hal,
God forgive thee for it: before I knew thee Hal, I knew nothing, and now am I, if a man should speak truly, little better
than one of the wicked: I must give over this life, and I will
give it over: by the Lord if I do not, I am a villain, I will be
damned for never a kings son in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Where shall we take a purse tomorrow Iacke?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
S'wounds where thou wilt lad, I will make one, if I do not
call me villain and baffle me.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
I see a good amendment of life in thee, from praying
to purse-taking.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Why Hall, it is my vocation Hall, it is no sin for a man
to labour in his vocation.
Enter Poines. Poynes now shall we know if Gadshill have set a match.
O if men were to be saved by merit, what hole in hell were hot
enough for him? this is the most omnipotent villain that ever
cried, stand, to a true man.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Good morrow Ned.

sp.speaker: Poines.
sp.p:
Good morrow sweet Hal. What says Monsieur
remorse? what says sir Iohn Sack, and Sugar Iacke? howe
agrees the Devil and thee about thy soul that thou soldest
him on good friday last, for a cup of Medeira and a cold capons
leg.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn stands to his word, the devil shall have his
bargain, for he was never yet a breaker of proverbs: he will
give the devil his due.

sp.speaker: Poynes.
sp.p:
Then art thou damned for keeping thy word with
the devil.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Else he had been damned for cozening the devil.

sp.speaker: Poy.
sp.p:
But my lads, my lads, tomorrow morning, by four
o'clock early at Gadshill, there are pilgrims going to Canturburie with rich offerings, and traders riding to London with fat
purses. I have vizards for you all you have horses for yourselves,
Gadshill lies tonight in Rochester, I have bespoke supper tomorrow
night in Eastcheape: we may do it as secure as sleep,
if you will go I will stuff your purses full of crowns: if you will
not, tarry at home and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Hear ye Yedward, if I tarry at home and go not, I will
hang you for going.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: You will chops.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Hal, wilt thou make one?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Who I rob, I a thief? not I by my faith.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
There is neither honesty, manhood, nor good fellowship
in thee, nor thou camest not of the blood royal, if thou darest not
stand for ten shillings.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Well then, once in my days I will be a madcap.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Why that is well said.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Well, come what will, I will tarry at home.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: By the lord, I will be a traitor then, when thou art king.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I care not.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn, I prithee leave the prince and me alone, I will
lay him down such reasons for this adventure that he shall go.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Well, God give thee the spirit of persuasion, and him
the ears of profiting, that what thou speakest, may move, and
what he hears, may be believed, that the true prince may (for
recreation sake) prove a false thief, for the poor abuses of the
time want countenance: farewell, you shall find me in Eastcheap

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Farewell the latter spring, farewell Alhallowne summer.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p:
Now my good sweet honey Lord, ride with us tomorrow. I have a jest to execute, that I cannot manage alone.
Falstalffe, Haruey, Rossill, and Gadshil, shall rob those men that
we have already way-laid, yourself and I will not be there:
and when they have the booty, if you and I do not rob them,
cut this head off from my shoulders.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How shall we part with them in setting forth?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Why, we will set forth before or after them, and appoint
them a place of meeting, wherein it is at our pleasure to fail;
and then will they adventure upon the exploit themselves, which
they shall have no sooner achieved but we will set upon them.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Yea, but it is like that they will know us by our horses, by
our habits, and by every other appointment to be ourselves.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Tut, our horses they shall not see, I will tie them in the wood,
our vizards we will change after we leave them: and sirrah, I
have cases of Buckram for the nonce, to enmask our noted
outward garments.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Yea, but I doubt they will be too hard for us.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Well, for two of them, I know them to be as true bred
cowards as ever turned back: and for the third, if he fight longer
than he sees reason, I will forswear arms. The virtue of this jest
will be the incomprehensible lies, that this same fat rogue will tell
us when we meet at supper, how thirty at least he fought with,
what wards, what blows, what extremities he endured, and in
the reproof of this lives the jest.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Well, I will go with thee, provide us all things necessary, and meet me tomorrow night in Eastcheape, there I will
sup: farewell.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Farewell my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I know you all, and will a while uphold
The unyoked humour of your idleness,
Yet herein will I imitate the sun,
Who doth permit the base contagious clouds
To smother up his beauty from the world,
That when he please again to be himself,
Being wanted he may be more wondered at
By breaking through the foul and ugly mists
Of vapours, that did seem to strangle him.
If all the year were playing holy-days,
To sport would be as tedious as to work;
But when they seldom come, they wished for come,
And nothing pleaseth but rare accidents:
So when this loose behaviour I throw off,
And pay the debt I never promised,
By how much better than my word I am,
By so much shall I falsify men's hopes,
And like bright metal on a sullen ground,
My reformation glittering over my fault,
Shall show more goodly, and attract more eyes
Than that which hath no foil to set it off.
I will so offend, to make offence a skill,
Redeeming time when men think least I will.

div2.stage: Enter the King, Northumberland, Worcester, Hotspur, sir Walter blunt, with others.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My blood hath been too cold and temperate,
Unapt to stir at these indignities,
And you have found me, for accordingly
You tread upon my patience, but be sure
I will from henceforth rather be myself
Mighty, and to be feared, than my condition
Which hath been smooth as oil, soft as young down,
And therefore lost that title of respect,
Which the proud soul near pays but to the proud.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Our house (my sovereign liege) little deserves
The scourge of greatness to be used on it,
And that same greatness too, which our own hands
Have helped to make so portly.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Worcester get thee gone, for I do see
Danger, and disobedience inthine eye:
O sir, your presence is too bold and peremptory,
And Majesty might never yet endure
The moody frontier of a servant brow,
You have good leave to leave us, when we need
Your use and counsel we shall send for you.
You were about to speak.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Yea my good Lord.
Those prisoners in your highness name demanded,
Which Harry Percy here at Holmedon took,
Were as he says, not with such strength denied
As is delivered to your majesty.
Either envy therefore, or misprision,
Is guilty of this fault, and not my son.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: My liege, I did deny no prisoners,
But I remember when the fight was done,
When I was dry with rage, and extreme toil,
Breathless and faint, leaning upon my sword,
Came there a certain Lord, neat and trimly dressed,
Fresh as a bridegroom, and his chin new rept,
Showed like a stubble land at harvest home,
He was perfumed like a Milliner,
And twixt his finger and his thumb he held
A pouncet box, which ever and anon
He gave his nose, and took it away again,
Who therewith angry, when it next came there
Took it in snuff, and still he smiled and talked:
And as the soldiers bore dead bodies by,
He called them untaught knaves, unmannerly,
To bring a slovenly unhandsome coarse
Betwixt the wind and his nobility:
With many holly-day and lady terms
He questioned me, amongst the rest demanded
My prisoners in your Majesty's behalf.
I then, all smarting with my wounds being cold,
To be so pestered with a Popinjay,
Out of my grief and my impatience
Answered neglectingly, I know not what
He should, or he should not, for he made me mad
To see him shine so brisk, and smell so sweet,
And talk so like a waiting gentlewoman,
Of guns, and drums, and wounds, God save the mark:
And telling me the sovereignest thing on earth
Was Spermaceti, for an inward bruise,
And that it was great pity, so it was,
This villainous saltpetre, should be digged
Out of the bowels of the harmless earth,
Which many a good tall fellow had destroyed
So cowardly, and but for these vile guns
He would himself have been a soldier.
This bald unjointed chat of his (my Lord)
I answered indirectly (as I said)
And I beseech you, let not his report
Come currant for an accusation
Betwixt my love and your high majesty.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: The circumstance considered, good my lord,
What ere Lord Harry Percie then had said
To such a person, and in such a place,
At such a time, with all the rest retold,
May reasonably die, and never rise
To do him wrong, or any way impeach
What then he said, so he unsay it now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why yet he doth deny his prisoners,
But with prouiso and exception,
That we at our own charge shall ransom straight
His brother-in-law, the foolish Mortimer,
Who on my soul, hath wilfully betrayed
The lives of those, that he did lead to fight
Against that great Magician, damned Glendower,
Whose daughter as we hear, that Earl of March
Hath lately married: shall our coffers then
Be emptied, to redeem a traitor home?
Shall we buy treason? and indent with fears
When they have lost and forfeited themselves?
No, on the barren mountains let him starve:
For I shall never hold that man my friend,
Whose tongue shall ask me for one penny cost
To ransom home revolted Mortimer,

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Revolted Mortimer:
He never did fall off, my sovereign liege
But by the chance of war, to prove that true
Needs no more but one tongue: for all those wounds,
Those mouthed wounds which valiantly he took,
When on the gentle Seuerns sedgy bank,
In single opposition hand to hand,
He did confound the best part of an hour,
In changing hardiment with great Glendower,
Three times they breathed, and three times did they drink
Upon agreement of swift Seuerns flood,
Who then affrighted with their bloody looks,
Ran fearefully among the trembling reeds,
And hid his crisp-head in the hollow bank,
Blood-stained with these valiant combatants,
Never did bare and rotten policy
Colour her working with such deadly wounds,
Nor never could the noble Mortimer
Receive so many, and all willingly,
Then let not him be slandered with revolt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou dost belie him Percy, thou dost belie him,
He never did encounter with Glendower:
I tell thee, he durst as well have met the devil alone,
As Owen Glendower for an enemy.
Art thou not ashamed? but sirrah, henceforth
Let me not hear you speak of Mortimer:
Send me your prisoners with the speediest means,
Or you shall hear in such a kind from me
As will displease you. My Lord Northumberland:
We licence your departure with your son,
Send us your prisoners, or you will hear of it.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: And if the devil come and roar for them
I will not send them: I will after straight
And tell him so, for I will ease my heart,
Albeit I make a hazard of my head.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: What? drunk with choler, stay, and pause a while,
Here comes your uncle.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Speak of Mortimer?
S'wounds I will speak of him, and let my soul
Want mercy if I do not join with him:
Yea on his part, I will empty all these veins,
And shed my dear blood, drop by drop in the dust,
But I will lift the down-trod Mortimer
As high in the air as this unthankful king,
As this ingrate and cankered Bullingbrooke.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Brother, the king hath made your nephew mad.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Who struck this heat up after I was gone?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: He will forsooth have all my prisoners,
And when I urged the ransom once again
Of my wives brother, then his cheek looked pale,
And on my face he turned an eye of death,
Trembling even at the name of Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Worst.
sp.l: I cannot blame him, was not he proclaimed
By Richard that dead is, the next of blood?

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: He was, I heard the proclamation:
And then it was, when the unhappy king,
(Whose wrongs in us God pardon) did set forth
Upon his Irish expedition;
From whence he intercepted, did return
To be deposed, and shortly murdered.

sp.speaker: Worst.
sp.l: And for whose death, we in the worlds wide mouth
Live scandalised and foully spoken of.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: But soft, I pray you did king Richard then
Proclaim my brother Edmund Mortimer
Heir to the crown?

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: He did, myself did hear it.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Nay then I cannot blame his cousin king,
That wished him on the barren mountains starve,
But shall it be that you that set the crown
Upon the head of this forgetful man,
And for his sake wear the detested blot
Of murtherous subornation? shall it be
That you a world of curses undergo,
Being the agents, or base second means,
The cords, the ladder, or the hangman rather,
O pardon me, that I descend so low,
To show the line and the predicament,
Wherein you range under this subtle king!
Shall it for shame be spoken in these days,
Or fill up Chronicles in time to come,
That men of your nobility and power
Did gage them both in an unjust behalf,
(As both of you God pardon it, have done)
To put down Richard, that sweet lovely Rose,
And plant this thorne, this canker Bullingbrooke?
And shall it in more shame be further spoken,
That you are fooled, discarded, and shook off
By him, for whom these shames ye underwent?
No, yet time serves, wherein you may redeem
Your banished honours, and restore yourselves
Into the good thoughts of the world again:
Revenge the jeering and disdained contempt
Of this proud king, who studies day and night
To answer all the debt he owes to you,
Even with the bloody payment of your deaths:
Therefore I say.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Peace cousin, say no more.
And now I will unclasp a secret book,
And to your quick conceiving discontents
I will read you matter deep and dangerous,
As full of peril and adventurous spirit,
As to overwalk a Current roaring loud,
On the unsteadfast footing of a spear.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: If he fall in, god-night, or sink, or swim,
Send danger from the East unto the West.
So honour cross it, from the North to South,
And let them grapple: O the blood more stirs
To rouse a lion than to start a hare.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Imagination of some great exploit
Drives him beyond the bounds of patience.
By heaven methinks it were an easy leap,
To pluck bright honour from the pale faced moon,
Or dive into the bottom of the deep,
Where fathom line could never touch the ground,
And pluck up drowned honour by the locks,
So he that doth redeem her thence might wear
Without corival all her dignities,
But out upon this half faced fellowship.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: He apprehends a world of figures here,
But not the form of what he should attend,
Good cousin give me audience for a while.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Those same noble Scots that are your prisoners

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I will keep them all;
By God he shall not have a Scot of them,
No, if a Scot would save his soul he shall not.
I will keep them by this hand.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: You, start away,
And lend no ear unto my purposes:
Those prisoners you shall keep.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Nay I will: that is flat:
He said he would not ransom Mortimer,
Forbade my tongue to speak of Mortimer,
But I will find him when he lies asleep,
And in his ear I will hollow Mortimer:
Nay, I will have a starling shall be taught to speak
Nothing but Mortimer, and give it him
To keep his anger still in motion.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Hear you cousin a word.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: All studies here I solemnly defy,
Save how to gall and pinch this Bullenbrooke,
And that same sword and buckler Prince of Wales,
But that I think his father loves him not,
And would be glad he met with some mischance:
I would have him poisoned with a pot of ale.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Farewell kinsman, I will talk to you
When you are better tempered to attend.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Why what a wasp-stung and impatient fool
Art thou? to break into this woman's mood,
Tying thine ear to no tongue but thine own?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Why look you, I am whipped and scourged with rods,
Nettled, and stung with pismires, when I hear
Of this vile politician Bullingbrooke,
In Richards time, what do you call the place?
A plague upon it, it is in Glocestershire;
It was where the mad-cap duke his uncle kept
His uncle Yorke, where I first bowed my knee
Unto this king of smiles, this Bullenbrooke:
'sblood, when you and he came back from Rauenspurgh.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: At Barkly castle.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: You say true.
Why what a candy deal of courtesy,
This fawning greyhound then did proffer me,
Look when his infant fortune came to age,
And gentle Harry Percy, and kind cousin:
O the devil take such cozeners, god forgive me,
Good uncle tell your tale, I have done.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Nay, if you have not, to it again,
We will stay your leisure.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I have done I'faith.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Then once more to your Scottish prisoners,
Deliver them up without their ransom straight,
And make the Douglas son your only mean
For Powers in Scotland, which for divers reasons
Which I shall send you written, be assured
Will easily be granted you my Lord.
Your son in Scotland being thus employed,
Shall secretly into the bosom creep
Of that same noble prelate well-beloved,
The Archbishop.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Of Yorke, is it not?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: True, who bears hard
His brothers death at Bristow the lord Scroop,
I speak not this in estimation,
As what I think might be, but what I know
Is ruminated, plotted, and set down,
And only stays but to behold the face
Of that occasion that shall bring it on.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I smell it. Upon my life it will do well.

sp.speaker: Nort.
sp.l: Before the game is afoot thou still letst slip.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Why, it cannot choose but be a noble plot,
And then the power of Scotland, and of Yorke,
To join with Mortimer, ha.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: And so they shall.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: In faith it is exceedingly well aimed.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: And it is no little reason bids us speed,
To save our heads by raising of a head,
For bear ourselves as even as we can,
The king will always think him in our debt,
And think we think ourselves unsatisfied,
Till he hath found a time to pay us home.
And see already how he doth begin
To make us strangers to his looks of love.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: He does, he does, we will be revenged on him.

sp.speaker: Worst.
sp.l: Cousin farewell. No further go in this,
Then I by letters shall direct your course
When time is ripe, which will be suddenly,
I will steal to Glendower, and Lo: Mortimer,
Where you and Douglas, and our powers at once,
As I will fashion it shall happily meet,
To bear our fortunes in our own strong arms,
Which now we hold at much uncertainty.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Farewell good brother, we shall thrive I trust.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Uncle adieu: O let the hours be short,
Till fields, and blows, and groans, applaud our sport.

div2.stage: Enter a Carrier with a lanterne in his hand

sp.speaker: 1 Car.
sp.p:
Heigh ho. If it be not four by the day I will be hanged,
Charles wain is over the new Chimney, and yet our horse not
packed. What Ostler.

sp.speaker: Ost.
sp.p: Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: 1 Car.
sp.p:
I prithee Tom beat Cuts saddle, put a few flocks in
the point, poor jade is wrong in the withers, out of all cease.

sp.speaker: 2 Car.
sp.p:
Peas and beans are as dank here as a dog, and that
is the next way to give poor jades the bots: this house is turned
upside down since Robin Ostler died.

sp.speaker: 1 Car.
sp.p:
Poor fellow never joyed since the prise of Oats rose,
it was the death of him.

sp.speaker: 2 Car.
sp.p:
I think this be the most villainous house in all London
road for fleas, I am stung like a Tench.

sp.speaker: 1 Car.
sp.p: Like a Tench, by the Mass there is ne'er a King christen could be better bit than I have been since the first cock.

sp.speaker: 2 Car.
sp.p:
Why they will allow us ne'er a Iordane, and then we
leak in your chimney, and your chamber-lie breeds fleas like
a loach.

sp.speaker: 1 Car.
sp.p: What Ostler, come away and be hanged, come away.

sp.speaker: 2 Car.
sp.p: I have a gammon of bacon, and two razes of Ginger, to be delivered as far as Charing cross.

sp.speaker: 1 Car
sp.p:
Gods body, the Turkeys in my Pannier are quite starved: what Ostler? a plague on thee, hast thou never an eye in thy
head? canst not hear, and it were not as good deed as drink to
break the pate on thee, I am a very villain, come and be hanged,
hast no faith in thee?

sp.speaker: Gadshill.
sp.p: Good morrow Carriers, whats o'clock?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I think it be two o'clock.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
I prithee lend me thy lantern, to see my gelding in the
stable.

sp.speaker: 1 Car.
sp.p:
Nay by God soft, I know a trick worth two of that
I'faith.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: I pray thee lend me thine.

sp.speaker: 2 Car.
sp.p: Aye when canst tell? lend me thy lantern (quoth he) marry I will see thee hanged first.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
Sirrah Carrier, what time do you mean to come to
London?

sp.speaker: 2 Car.
sp.p:
Time enough to go to bed with a candle, I warrant
thee, come neighbour Mugs, we will call up the Gentlemen,
they will along with company, for they have great charge.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: What ho: Chamberlain.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: At hand quoth pickpurse.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
that is even as fair as at hand quoth the Chamberlain:
for thou variest no more from picking of purses, than giving direction doth from labouring: thou layest the plot how.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Good morrow master Gadshill, it holds currant that
I told you yesternight, there is a Franklin in the wild of Kent
hath brought three hundred Marks with him in gold, I heard
him tell it to one of his company last night at supper, a kind of
Auditor, one that hath abundance of charge too, God knows
what, they are up already, and call for Eggs and butter, they will
away presently.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
Sirrah, if they meet not with Saint Nicholas clerks,
I will give thee this neck.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
No, I will none of it, I pray thee keep that for the hangman, for I know thou worshippest Saint Nicholas, as truly as
a man of falsehood may.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
What talkest thou to me of the hangman? if I hang, I will make
a fat pair of Gallows: for if I hang, old sir Iohn hangs with
me, and thou knowest he is no starveling: tut, there are other
Trojans that thou dreamest not of, the which for sport sake are
content to do the profession, some grace, that would (if matters
should be looked into) for their own credit sake make all whole.
I am joined with no footland rakers, no long-staff sixpenny
strikers, none of these mad mustachio purple-hued moult-worms,
but with nobility, and tranquillity, Burgomaster and great
Ones, such as can hold in such as will strike sooner than speak,
and speak sooner than drink, and drink sooner than pray, and
yet (s'wounds) I lie, for they pray continually to their Saint the
Common-wealth, or rather not pray to her, but pray on her, for
they ride up and down on her, and make her their boots.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
What, the Common-wealth their boots? will she
hold out water in foul way?

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
She will, she will, Justice hath liquored her: we steal as
in a Castle cocksure: we have the receipt of Ferneseede, we
walk invisible.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Nay by my faith, I think you are more beholding to
the night than to Ferneseed, for your walking invisible.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, thou shalt have a share in our purchase, as I am a true man.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Nay rather let me have it, as you are a false thief.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
Go to, homo is a common name to all men: bid the Ostler
bring my gelding out of the stable, farewell you muddy knave.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Come shelter, shelter, I have removed Falstalffes horse,
and he frets like a gummed Velvet.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Stand close.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Poynes, Poynes, and be hanged Poynes.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Peace ye fat-kidneyed rascal, what a brawling dost thou
keep?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Wheres Poynes Hall?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: He is walked up to the top of the hill, I will go seek him.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I am accursed to rob in that thieves company, the rascal
hath removed my horse, and tied him I know not where, if I
travel but four foot by the squire further a foot, I shall break
my wind. Well, I doubt not but to die a fair death for all
this, if I scape hanging for killing that rogue. I have forsworn
his company hourly any time this xxii. years, and yet I am bewitched with the rogues company. If the rascal have not given me medicines to make me love him, I will be hanged. It could
not be else, I have drunk medicines, Poynes, Hall, a plague
upon you both. Bardoll, Peto, I will starve ere I will rob a foot
further, and it were not as good a deed as drink to turn true man, and to leave these rogues, I am the veriest varlet that ever
chewed with a tooth: eight yards of uneven ground is threescore and ten miles a foot with me, and the stony hearted
villains know it well enough, a plague upon it when thieves
cannot be true one to another:
They whistle, Whew, a plague upon you all, give me my horse you rogues,
give me my horse and be hanged:

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Peace ye fat guts, lie down, lay thine ear close to the
ground, and list if thou canst hear the tread of travellers.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Have you any levers to lift me up again being down,
'sblood I will not bear mine own flesh so far a foot again for
all the coin in thy fathers Exchequer: What a plague mean
ye to colt me thus?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Thou liest, thou art not colted, thou art uncolted.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I prithee good prince, Hal, help me to my horse, good
kings son.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Out ye rogue, shall I be your Ostler?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Hang thyself in thine own heir apparent garters,
if I be taken, I will peach for this: and I have not Ballads made on
you all, and sung to filthy tunes, let a cup of sack be my
poison, when a jest is so forward, and a foot too I hate it.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: Stand.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: So I do against my will.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: O it is our setter, I know his voice, Bardoll, what news.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Case ye, case ye on with your vizards, there is money
of the kings coming down the hill, it is going to the Kings
Exchequer.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: You lie ye rogue, it is going to the kings Tavern.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: There is enough to make us all:

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: To be hanged.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Sirs you four shall front them in the narrow lane: Ned
Poines, and I will walk lower, if they scape from your encounter, then they light on us.

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.p: How many be there of them?

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: Some eight or ten.

sp.speaker: Fal
sp.p: S'wounds will they not rob us?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What, a coward sir Iohn paunch.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Indeed I am not Iohn of Gaunt your grandfather, but
yet no coward, Hall.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Well, we leave that to the proof.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Sirrah Iacke, thy horse stands behind the hedge, when
thou needst him, there thou shalt find him: farewell and stand fast.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Now cannot I strike him if I should be hanged.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Ned, where are our disguises?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Here, hard by, stand close.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Now my masters, happy man be his dole, say I, every
man to his business.

sp.speaker: Trauel.
sp.p:
Come neighbour, the boy shall lead our horses down
the hill, we will walk a foot a while and ease our legs.

sp.speaker: Theeues.
sp.p: Stand.

sp.speaker: Trauel.
sp.p: Iesus bless us.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Strike, down with them, cut the villains throats, a
whoreson Caterpillars, bacon-fed knaves, they hate us youth,
down with them, fleece them.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: O we are undone, both we and ours for ever.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hang ye gor-bellied knaves, are ye undone, no ye fat
chuffs, I would your store were here: on bacons on, what ye
knaves young men must live, you are grand jurors, are ye, we will
jure ye faith.

div2.stage: Here they rob them and bind them.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
The thieves have bound the true men, now could
thou and I rob the thieves, and go merrily to London, it would
be argument for a week, laughter for a month, and a good jest
for ever.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Stand close, I hear them coming.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Come my masters, let us share and then to horse before
day, and the Prince and Poines be not two arrant cowards
there is no equity stirring, there is no more valour in that Poynes,
than in a wild duck.

div2.stage: As they are sharing the Prince and Poins

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Your money.

div2.stage: set vpon them, they all runne away, and

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Villains.

div2.stage: Falstaffe after a blow or two runs away too, leauing the bootie behind them.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Got with much ease. Now merrily to horse: the thieves
are all scattered, and possessed with fear so strongly, that they dare
not meet each other, each takes his fellow for an officer, away
good Ned, Falstalffe sweats to death, and lards the lean earth
as he walks along, wert not for laughing I should pity him.

sp.speaker: Poynes.
sp.l: How the rogue roared.

div2.stage: Enter Hotspur solus reading a letter.

sp.p:
But for mine own part my Lord I could be well contented to be
there, in respect of the love I bear your house.
He could be contented, why is he not then? in the respect of
the love he bears our house: he shows in this, he loves his own
barn better than he loves our house. Let me see some more.
The purpose you undertake is dangerous,
Why that is certain, it is dangerous to take a cold, to sleep, to
drink, but I tell you (my Lord fool) out of this nettle danger, we
pluck this flower safety.
The purpose you undertake is dangerous, the friends you have named uncertain, the time itself unguarded, and your whole plot too
light, for the counterpoise of so great an opposition.
Say you so, say you so, I say unto you again, you are a shallow cowardly hind, and you lie: what a lack brain is this? by
the Lord our plot is a good plot, as ever was laid, our friends true
and constant: a good plot, good friends, and full of expectation: an
excellent plot, very good friends; what a frosty spirited rogue is
this? why my Lord of York commends the plot, and the general course of the Action. S'wounds if I were now by this rascal I could brain him with his Ladies fan. Is there not my
father, my uncle, and myself; Lord Edmond Mortimer, my
Lord of Yorke, and Owen Glendower: is there not besides the
Dowglas, have I not all their letters to meet me in arms by the
ninth of the next month, and are they not some of them set forward already? What a pagan rascal is this, an infidel? Ha, you
shall see now in very sincerity of fear and cold heart, will he to
the King, and lay open all our proceedings? O I could divide
myself, and go to buffets, for moving such a dish of skim milk
with so honourable an action. Hang him, let him tell the king, we
are prepared: I will set forward tonight.
Enter his Lady. How now Kate, I must leave you within these two hours.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O my good Lord, why are you thus alone?
For what offence have I this fortnight been
A banished woman from my Harries bed?
Tell me sweet Lord, what is it that takes from thee
Thy stomach, pleasure, and thy golden sleep?
Why dost thou bend thine eyes upon the earth?
And start so often when thou sittest alone?
Why hast thou lost the fresh blood in thy cheeks?
And given my treasures and my rights of thee
To thick eyed musing, and cursed melancholy?
In thy faint slumbers I by thee have watched,
And heard the murmur, tales of iron wars,
Speak terms of manage to thy bounding steed,
Cry courage to the field. And thou hast talked
Of sallies, and retires of trenches tents,
Of palisades, frontiers, parapets,
Of basilisks, of canon, culverin,
Of prisoners ransom, and of soldiers slain,
And all the currents of a heady fight.
Thy spirit within thee hath been so at war,
And thus hath so bestirrred thee in thy sleep,
That beads of sweat have stood upon thy brow
Like bubbles in a late disturbed stream
And in thy face strange motions have appeared,
Such as we see when men restrain their breath,
On some great sudden hest. O what portents are these?
Some heavy business hath my Lord in hand,
And I must know it else he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: What ho, is Gilliams with the packet gone?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He is my Lord, an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Hath Butler brought those horses from the Sheriff?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: One horse my Lord he brought even now.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: What horse, Roan? a crop-ear is it not?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: It is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: That roan shall be my throne. Well, I will back him
straight: O Esperance, bid Butler lead him forth into the park.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But hear you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: What sayst thou my Lady?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What is it carries you away?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Why, my horse (my love) my horse.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Out you mad-headed ape, a weasel hath not such a deal
of spleen as you are tossed with. In faith I will know your business
Harry that I will, I fear my brother Mortimer doth stir about
his title, and hath sent for you to line his enterprise, but if you go.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: So far afoot I shall be weary love.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Come, come you Parakeet, answer me directly unto
this question that I ask, in faith I will break thy little finger Harry and if thou wilt not tell me all things true.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Away, away you trifler, love, I love thee not,
I care not for thee Kate, this is no world
To play with mammets, and to tilt with lips,
We must have bloody noses, and cracked crowns,
And pass them currant too: gods me my horse:
What sayst thou Kate? what wouldst thou have with me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do you not love me? do you not indeed?
Well, do not then, for since you love me not
I will not love myself. Do you not love me?
Nay tell me if you speak in jest or no?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Come, wilt thou see me ride?
And when I am a horseback I will swear
I love thee infinitely. But hark you Kate,
I must not have you henceforth question me
Whither I go, nor reason where about,
Whither I must, I must, and to conclude
This evening must I leave you gentle Kate,
I know you wise, but yet no farther wise
Than Harry Percies wife, constant you are,
But yet a woman, and for secrecy
No Lady closer, for I well believe
Thou wilt not utter what thou dost not know,
And so far will I trust thee gentle Kate.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How, so far.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Not an inch further, but hark you Kate,
Whither I go, thither shall you go too:
Today will I set forth, tomorrow you,
Will this content you Kate?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It must of force.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Ned, prithee come out of that fat room, and lend me
thy hand to laugh a little.

sp.speaker: Poi.
sp.p: Where hast been Hal?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
With three or four loggerheads, amongst three or
fourscore hogsheads. I have sounded the very base string of
humility. Sirrah, I am sworn brother to a leash of drawers, and
can call them all by their christen names, as Tom, Dicke, and
Francis, they take it already upon their salvation, that though I
be but prince of Wales, yet I am the king of Courtesy, and tell me
flatly I am no proud Iacke like Falstalffe, but a Corinthian, a lad
of metal, a good boy (by the Lord so they call me) and when I
am king of England I shall command all the good lads in Eastcheape. They call drinking deep, dying scarlet, and when you
breath in your watering they cry hem, and bid you play it off.
To conclude, I am so good a proficient in one quarter of an hour
that I can drink with any Tinker in his own language, during
my life. I tell thee Ned thou hast lost much honour, that thou
wert not with me in this action; but sweet Ned, to sweeten
which name of Ned, I give thee this pennyworth of sugar, clapped even now into my hand by an underskinker, one that never spake
other English in his life than eight shillings and six pence, and
you are welcome, with this shrill addition, anon, anon sir; score a
pint of bastard in the half moon, or so. But Ned, to drive away the time till Falstalffe come: I prithee do thou stand in
some by-room, while I question my puny drawer to what end
he gave me the sugar, and do thou never leave calling Frances,
that his tale to me may be nothing but anon, step aside and I will
show thee a present.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Frances.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Thou art perfect.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Frances.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Anon, anon sir. Look down into the Pomgarnet,
Ralphe.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Come hither Frances.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How long hast thou to serve Frances?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Forsooth, five years, and as much as too.

sp.speaker: Poi.
sp.p: Frances.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Five year, byrlady a long lease for the clinking of pewter; but Frances, darest thou be so valiant, as to play the coward
with thy Indenture, and show it a fair pair of heels, and run
from it?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O Lord sir, I will be sworn upon all the books in England, I could find in my heart.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Frances.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How old art thou Frances?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me see, about Michaelmas next I shall be.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Frances.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon sir, pray stay a little my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Nay but hark you Frances, for the sugar thou gavest
me, it was a pennyworth, wast not?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O Lord, I would it had been two.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
I will give thee for it a thousand pound, ask me when
thou wilt, and thou shalt have it,

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Frances.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Anon Frances, no Frances, but tomorrow Frances: or
Frances a Thursday; or indeed Fraunces when thou wilt. But
Fraunces.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Wilt thou rob this leathern Jerkin, crystal button, notpated, agate ring, puke stocking, Caddice garter, smooth tongue,
spanish pouch?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O Lord sir, who do you mean?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Why then your brown bastard is your only drink? for
look you Fraunces, your white canvas doublet will sully. In
Barbary sir, it cannot come to so much.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Frances.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Away you rogue, dost thou not hear them call.

div2.stage: Here they both cal him, the Drawer stands amazed not knowing which way to go.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p:
What standest thou still and hearst such a calling? look
to the guests within. My Lord, old sir Iohn with half a dozen
more are at the door, shall I let them in?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Let them alone awhile, and then open the door: Poines.

sp.speaker: Poi.
sp.p: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Sirrah, Falstalffe and the rest of the thieves are at the
door, shall we be merry?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
As merry as Crickets my lad, but hark ye, what cunning
match have you made with this jest of the Drawer: come whats
the issue?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
I am now of all humours, that have showed themselves
humours since the old days of good man Adam, to the pupil
age of this present twelve o'clock at midnight. Whats o'clock
Frances?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
That ever this fellow should have fewer words than a
Parrot, and yet the son of a woman. His industry is up stairs
and down stairs, his eloquence the parcel of a reckoning. I am
not yet of Percyes mind, the Hotspur of the North, he that kills
me some six or seven dozen of Scots at a breakfast: washes
his hands, and says to his wife, fie upon this quiet life, I want
work. O my sweet Harry says she! how many hast thou killed
today? Give my roan horse a drench (says he) and answers some fourteen, an hour after: a trifle, a trifle. I prithee
call in Falstalffe, I will play Percy, and that damned brawn shall
play dame Mortimer his wife. Riuo says the drunkard: call in
Ribs, call in Tallow.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Welcome Iacke, where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
A plague of all cowards I say, and a vengeance too, marry and Amen: give me a cup of sack boy. Ear I lead this life
long, I will sow netherstocks and mend them, and foot them too.
A plague of all cowards. Give me a cup of sack rogue, is there
no virtue extant?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Didst thou never see Titan kiss a dish of butter, pitiful
hearted Titan that melted at the sweet tale of the sons, if thou
didst, then behold that compound.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
You rogue, here is lime in this sack too: there is nothing but roguery to be found in villainous man, yet a coward is
worse than a cup of sack with lime in it. A villainous coward.
Go thy ways old Iacke, die when thou wilt, if manhood, good
manhood be not forgot upon the face of the earth, then am I a
shotten herring: there lives not three good men unhanged in
England, and one of them is fat, and grows old, God help the
while, a bad world I say, I would I were a weaver. I could sing
psalms, or anything. A plague of all cowards I say still.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How now Wool sack, what mutter you?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
A kings son, if I do not beat thee out of thy kingdom
with a dagger of lath, and drive all thy subjects afore thee like a
flock of wild geese, I will never wear hair on my face more, you
prince of Wales.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Why you whoreson round-man, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Are not you a coward? answer me to that, and
Poines there.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p:
S'wounds ye fat paunch, if ye call me coward by the
Lord I will stab thee.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I call thee coward, I will see thee damned ere I call thee
coward, but I would give a thousand pound I could run as
fast as thou canst. You are straight enough in the shoulders, you
care not who sees your back: call you that backing of your
friends, a plague upon such backing, give me them that will
face me, give me a cup of sack. I am a rogue if I drunk today.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: O villain, thy lips are scarce wiped since thou drunkest last.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
All is one for that.
He drinketh. A plague of all cowards still say I.

sp.speaker: Prin,
sp.p: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Whats the matter, there be four of us here have taken a
thousand pound this day morning

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Where is it Iacke, where is it?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Where is it? taken from us it is: a hundred upon poor
four of us.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What, a hundred, man?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I am a rogue if I were not at half sword with a dozen
of them two hours together. I have scaped by miracle. I am
eight times thrust through the doublet, four through the hose,
my buckler cut through and through, my sword hacked like a
handsaw, ecce signum. I never dealt better since I was a man, all
would not do. A plague of all cowards, let them speak, if they
speak more or less than truth, they are villains, and the sons
of darkness.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: Speak sirs, how was it?

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p: We four set upon some dozen.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Sixteen at least my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p: And bound them.

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.p: No, no, they were not bound.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
You rogue they were bound every man of them, or
I am a Iew else: an Hebrew Iew.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p:
As we were sharing, some six or seven fresh men set
upon us.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: And unbound the rest, and then come in the other.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What, fought you with them all?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
All, I know not what you call all, but if I fought not with
fifty of them I am a bunch of radish: if there were not two or
three and fifty upon poor old Iacke, then am I no two legged
Creature.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Pray God you have not murdered some of them.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Nay, that is past praying for, I have peppered two of them.
Two I am sure I have paid, two rogues in buckram suits: I tell
thee what Hall, if I tell thee a lie, spit in my face; call me horse,
thou knowest my old ward: here I lay, and thus I bore my
point, four rogues in Buckram let drive at me.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: What four? thou saidst but two even now.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Four Hal, I told thee four.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, he said four.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
These four came all a front, and mainly thrust at me,
I made me no more ado, but took all their seven points in my
target, thus.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Seven, why there were but four even now.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: In Buckram.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Aye four in Buckram suites.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Seven by these hilts, or I am a villain else.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Prithee let him alone, we shall have more anon.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Doest thou hear me Hal?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Aye, and mark thee too iacke.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Do so, for it is worth the listening to, these nine in Buckram that I told thee of.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: So, two more already.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Their points being broken.

sp.speaker: Poy.
sp.p: Down fell their hose.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Began to give me ground: but I followed me close, came
in, foot, and hand, and with a thought, seven of the eleven I paid.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: O monstrous! eleven Buckram men grown out of two.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
But as the devil would have it, three misbegotten knaves
in Kendall green came at my back, and let drive at me, for it
was so dark Hal, that thou couldest not see thy hand.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
These lies are like their father that begets them, gross as
a mountain, open, palpable. Why thou clay-brained guts, thou
knotty-pated fool, thou whoreson obscene greasy tallow-catch.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
What art thou mad? art thou mad? is not the truth the
truth?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Why, how couldst thou know these men in Kendal green
when it was so dark thou couldst not see thy hand, come tell us
your reason. What sayst thou to this?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Come your reason, Iacke, your reason.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
What, upon compulsion: S'wounds, if I were at the
strappado, or all the racks in the world, I would not tell you on
compulsion. Give you a reason on compulsion? if reasons were
as plentiful as blackberries, I would give no man a reason upon
compulsion, I.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
I will be no longer guilty of this sin. This sanguine coward, this bed-presser, this horse-back-breaker, this huge hill
of flesh.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
'sblood you starveling, you eel-skin, you dried neats-tongue, you
bull's pizzle, you stock fish: O for breath to utter what is like thee,
you tailors yard, you sheath, you bowcase, you vile standing tuck.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Well, breath a while, and then to it again, and when thou
hast tired thyself in base comparisons hear me speak but this.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Mark iacke.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
We two saw you four set on four, and bound them and
were masters of their wealth: mark now how a plain tale shall
put you down, then did we two set on you four, and with a
word out-faced you from your prize, and have it, yea and can show
it you here in the house: and Falstalffe you carried your guts away as nimbly, with as quick dexterity, and roared for mercy, and
still run and roared, as ever I heard bull calf. What a slave art thou
to hack thy sword as thou hast done? and then say it was in
fight. What trick? what device? what starting hole canst thou
now find out, to hide thee from this open and apparent shame?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Come, let us hear iacke, what trick hast thou now?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
By the Lord, I knew ye as well as he that made ye. Why
hear you my masters, was it for me to kill the heir apparent?
should I turn upon the true prince? why thou knowest I am as
valiant as Hercules: but beware instinct, the lion will not touch
the true prince, instinct is a great matter. I was now a coward
on instinct, I shall think the better of myself, and thee during
my life; I for a valiant lion, and thou for a true prince: but by
the Lord, lads, I am glad you have the money, Hostess clap to
the doors, watch tonight, pray tomorrow, gallants, lads,
boys, hearts of gold, all the titles of good fellowship come
to you. What shall we be merry, shall we have a play extempore?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Content, and the argument shall be thy running away.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: A, no more of that Hal if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: O Iesu, my Lord the prince!

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How now my lady the hostess, what sayst thou to me?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p:
Marry my Lo. there is a noble man of the court at door
would speak with you: he says he comes from your father.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Give him as much as will make him a royal man, and
send him back again to my mother.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: An old man.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
What doth gravity out of his bed at midnight? Shall I
give him his answer?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Prithee do iacke.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Faith and I will send him packing.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Now sirs, byrlady you fought fair, so did you Peto, so
did you Bardol, you are lions, too you ran away upon instinct, you
will not touch the true prince, no fie.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Faith I ran when I saw others run.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Faith tell me now in earnest, how came Falstalffs sword
so hacked?

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.p:
Why, he hacked it with his dagger, and said he would
swear truth out of England, but he would make you believe
it was done in fight, and persuaded us to do the like.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Yea, and to tickle our noses with spear-grass, to make
them bleed, and then to beslobber our garments with it, and
swear it was the blood of true men. I did that I did not this seven year before, I blushed to hear his monstrous devices.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
O villain, thou stolest a cup of Sack eighteen years
ago, and wert taken with the manner, and ever since thou hast
blushed extempore, thou hadst fire and sword on thy side, and yet
thou rannest away, what instinct hadst thou for it?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
My Lord do you see these meteors? do you behold these
exhalations?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What think you they portend?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Hot livers, and cold purses.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Choler, my Lord, if rightly taken.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
No if rightly taken halter. Here comes lean iacke, here
comes bare bone: how now my sweet creature of bombast,
how long is it ago iacke since thou sawest thine own knee?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
My own knee, when I was about thy years (Hall) I was
not an Eagles talent in the waste, I could have crept into any
Alderman's thumb ring: a plague of sighing and grief, it blows
a man up like a bladder. There is villainous news abroad, here
was sir Iohn Bracy, from your father: you must to the court in
the morning. That same mad fellow of the North Percie, and
he of Wales that gave Amamon the bastinado, and made Lucifer cuckold, and swore the devil his true liegeman upon the cross
of a Welsh hook: what a plague call you him?

sp.speaker: Poynes.
sp.p: O Glendower.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Owen, Owen, the same, and his son-in-law Mortimer, and old Northumberland, and that sprightly Scot of
Scots, Dowglas, that runs a horseback up a hill perpendicular.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
He that rides at high speed, and with his pistol kills a
sparrow flying.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: You have hit it.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: So did he never the sparrow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Well, that rascal hath good mettle in him, he will not
run.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Why, what a rascal art thou then, to praise him so for
running?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
A-horseback (ye cuckoo) but afoot he will not budge
a foot.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Yes Iacke, upon instinct.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I grant ye upon instinct: well he is there too, and one
Mordacke, and a thousand blue caps more. Worcester is stolen
away tonight, thy fathers beard is turned white with the news,
you may buy land now as cheap as stinking Mackerel.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Why then, it is like if there come a hot June, and this
civil buffeting hold, we shall buy maidenheads as they buy hob
nails, by the hundreds.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
By the mass lad thou sayst true, it is like we shall have
good trading that way: but tell me Hall, art not thou horrible
afeared? thou being heir apparent, could the world pick thee
out three such enemies again? as that fiend Dowglas, that spirit Percy, and that devil Glendower, art thou not horribly afraid?
doth not thy blood drill at it?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Not a whit i'faith, I lack some of thy instinct.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Well thou wilt be horribly chid tomorrow when
thou comest to thy father, if thou love me practise an answer.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Do thou stand for my father and examine me upon the
particulars of my life.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Shall I: content. This chair shall be my state, this dagger my sceptre, and this cushion my crown.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Thy state is taken for a joined stool, thy golden sceptre
for a leaden dagger, and thy precious rich crown for a pitiful
bald crown.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Well, if the fire of grace be not quite out of thee
now shalt thou be moved. Give me a cup of Sack to make
my eyes look red, that it may be thought I have wept,
for I must speak in passion, and I will do it in king Cambises
vain.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Well, here is my leg.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: And here is my speech; stand aside Nobility.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: O Iesu, this is excellent sport i'faith.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Weep not sweet Queen, for trickling tears are vain.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: O the father, how he holds his countenance?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: For Gods sake Lords, convey my trustful Queen,
For tears do stop the floodgates of her eyes.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
O Iesu, he doth it as like one of these harlotry players as
ever I see.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: Peace good pint-pot, peace good tickle-brain.
sp.p:
Harrie, I do not only marvel where thou spendest thy
time, but also how thou art accompanied. For though the chamomile the more it is trodden on, the faster it grows: so youth
the more it is wasted, the sooner it wears: that thou art my son
I have partly thy mothers word, partly my own opinion, but
chiefly a villainous trick of thine eye, and a foolish hanging
of thy nether lip, that doth warrant me. If then thou be
son to me, here lies the point, why being son to me, art
thou so pointed at? shall the blessed sun of heaven prove a micher, and eat black-berries? a question not to be asked. Shall the
son of England prove a thief, and take purses? a question to
be asked. There is a thing Harry, which thou hast often heard of,
and it is known to many in our land by the name of pitch. This
pitch (as ancient writers do report) doth defile, so doth the company thou keepest: for Harrie now, I do not speak to thee in
drink, but in tears; not in pleasure but in passion: not in words
only, but in woes also: and yet there is a virtuous man, whom
I have often noted in thy company, but I know not his name.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What manner of man if it like your Majesty?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
A goodly portly man i'faith, and a corpulent of a cheerful
look, a pleasing eye, and a most noble carriage, and as I think
his age some fifty, or byrlady inclining to threescore, and now
I remember me, his name is Falstalffe, if that man should be
lewdly given, he deceiveth me. For Harry, I see virtue in his
looks: if then the tree may be known by the fruit, as the fruit
by the tree, then peremptorily I speak it, there is virtue in that
Falstalffe, him keep with, the rest banish, and tell me now thou
naughty varlet, tell me where hast thou been this month?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Dost thou speak like a king, do thou stand for me, and
I will play my father.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Depose me, if thou dost it half so gravely, so majestically, both in word and matter, hang me up by the heels for a rabbit sucker, or a poulters Hare

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Well, here I am set.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And here I stand, judge my masters.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Now Harry, whence come you?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: My noble Lord from Eastcheape.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: The complaints I hear of thee are grievous.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
'sblood my Lord they are false: nay I will tickle ye for a young
prince I'faith.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Swearest thou ungracious boy, hence forth ne'er look
on me, thou art violently carried away from grace, there is a devil haunts thee in the likeness of an old fat man, a tun of man
is thy companion: why doest thou converse with that trunk of
humours, that boulting hutch of beastliness, that swollen parcel
of dropsies that huge bombard of sack, that stuffed cloak-bag of
guts, that roasted Manningtre Ox with the pudding in his belly,
that reverent vice, that gray iniquity, that father ruffian, that unity in years, wherein is he good, but to taste sack and drink it?
wherein neat and cleanly, but to carve a capon and eat it? wherein
cunning, but in craft? wherein crafty, but in villainy? wherein villainous, but in all things? wherein worthy, but in nothing?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I would your grace would take me with you, whom
means your grace?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: That villainous abominable misleader of youth, Falstalffe, that old white bearded Satan.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: My Lord, the man I know.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: I know thou doest.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
But to say I know more harm in him than in myself,
were to say more than I know: that he is old the more the pity, his white hairs do witness it, but that he is saving your reverence, a whoremaster, that I utterly deny: if sack and sugar
be a fault, God help the wicked; if to be old and merry be a sin,
then many an old host that I know is damned: if to be fat be to be
hated, then Pharaohs lane kine are to be loved. No my good lord
banish Peto, banish Bardoll, banish Poines, but for sweet Iacke
Falstalffe, kind Iacke Falstalffe, true Iacke Falstalffe, valiant
Iacke Falstalffe, and therefore more valiant being as he is old Iacke
Falstalffe, banish not him thy Harries company, banish not
him thy Harries company, banish plump Iacke, and banish all
the world.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: I do, I will.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
O my Lord, my Lord, the Sheriff with a most monstrous
watch is at the door.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Out ye rogue, play out the play, I have much to say in
the behalf of that Falstalffe.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: O Iesu, my Lord, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Heigh, heigh, the Devil rides upon a fiddle stick, whats
the matter?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
The Sheriff and all the watch are at the door, they are
come to search the house, shall I let them in?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Doest thou hear Hal? never call a true piece of gold a
counterfeit, thou art essentially made without seeming so.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: And thou a natural coward without instinct.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I deny your Mayor, if you will deny the Sheriff so, if not,
let him enter. If I become not a Cart as well as another man, a
plague on my bringing up, I hope I shall as soon be strangled
with a halter as another.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Go hide thee behind the Arras, the rest walk up above,
now my masters for a true face, and good conscience.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Both which I have had, but their date is out, and therefore I will hide me.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Call in the Sheriff.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Now master Sheriff, what is your will with me?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: First pardon me my Lord. A hue and cry hath followed
certain men unto this house.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What men?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: One of them is well known my gracious Lord, a gross
fat man.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: As fat as butter.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: The man I do assure you is not here,
For I myself at this time have employed him:
And Sheriff, I will engage my word to thee,
That I will by tomorrow dinner time
Send him to answer thee or any man,
For anything he shall be charged withal,
And so let me entreat you leave the house.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: I will my Lord: there are two gentlemen
Have in this robbery lost 300. marks.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: It may be so: if he have robbed these men
He shall be answerable, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: God night my noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I think it is god morrow is it not?

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: Indeed my Lord I think it be two o'clock.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: This oily rascal is known as well as Poules: go call
him forth.

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.l: Falstalffe: fast asleep behind the Arras, and snorting
like a horse.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Hark how hard he fetches breath, search his pockets.

div2.stage: He searcheth his pocket, and findeth certaine papers.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What hast thou found?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nothing but papers my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Let us see what they be, read them.
Item a capon. two shillings, twopence
Item sauce. fourpence
Item sack two gallons. five shillings, eightpence
Item anchovies and sack after supper. two shillings, sixpence
Item bread. ob.

sp.p:
O monstrous! but one halfpennyworth of bread to this intolerable deal of sack? what there is else keep close, we will read it at
more advantage; there let him sleep till day, I will to the court in
the morning. We must all to the wars, and thy place shall be honourable. I will procure this fat rogue a charge of foot, and I know
his death will be a march of twelve score, the money shall be
paid back again with advantage; be with me betimes in the
morning, and so good morrow Peto.

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.p: Good morrow good my Lord.

div2.stage: Enter Hotspur, Worcester, Lord Mortimer, Owen Glendower.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: These promises are fair, the parties sure,
And our induction full of prosperous hope.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Lord Mortimer, and cousin Glendower will you sit down?
and Uncle Worcester; a plague upon it I have forgot the map.

sp.speaker: Glendow.
sp.l: No here it is; sit Cousin Percy, sit good Cousin
Hotspur, for by that name as oft as Lancaster doth speak of you,
his cheek looks pale, and with a rising sigh he wisheth you in
heaven.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: And you in hell, as oft as he hears Owen Glendower
spoke of.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: I cannot blame him; at my nativity
The front of heaven was full of fiery shapes
Of burning cressets, and at my birth
The frame and huge foundation of the earth
Shaked like a coward.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Why so it would have done at the same season if your
mothers cat had but kittened, though yourself had never been
born.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: I say the earth did shake when I was born.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: And I say the earth was not of my mind,
If you suppose as fearing you it shook.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: The heavens were all on fire, the earth did tremble,

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: O then the earth shook to see the heavens on fire,
And not in fear of your nativity,
Diseased nature oftentimes breaks forth,
In strange eruptions, oft the teeming earth
Is with a kind of colic pinched and vexed,
By the imprisoning of unruly wind
Within her womb, which for enlargement striving
Shakes the old Beldam earth, and topples down
Steeples and moss-grown towers. At your birth
Our Grandam earth, having this distemperature
In passion shook.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: Cousin of many men
I do not bear these crossings, give me leave
To tell you once again that at my birth
The front of heaven was full of fiery shapes,
The goats ran from the mountains, and the herds
Were strangely clamorous to the frighted fields.
These signs have marked me extraordinary,
And all the courses of my life do show
I am not in the roll of common men:
Where is he living clipped in with the sea,
That chides the banks of England, Scotland, Wales,
Which calls me pupil or hath read to me?
And bring him out that is but woman's son?
Can trace me in the tedious ways of Art,
And hold me pace in deep experiments.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I think there is no man speaks better Welsh:
I will to dinner.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Peace cousin Percy, you will make him mad.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: I can call spirits from the vasty deep.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Why so can I, or so can any man,
But will they come when you do call for them

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: Why I can teach you cousin to command the Devil.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: And I can teach thee coz to shame the devil,
By telling truth. Tell truth and shame the devil:
If thou have power to raise him bring him hither,
And I will be sworn I have power to shame him hence:
O while you live tell truth and shame the devil.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Come, come, no more of this unprofitable chat.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: Three times hath Henry Bullenbrooke made head
Against my power, thrice from the banks of Wye,
And sandy bottomed Seuerne have I sent him
Bootless home, and weather beaten back.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Home without boots, and in foul weather too,
How scapes he agues in the devils name?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: Come here is the map, shall we divide our right?
According to our three fold order taken.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The Archdeacon hath divided it
Into three limits very equally:
England from Trent, and Seuerne hitherto,
By South and East is to my part assigned:
All westward, Wales beyond the Seuerne shore,
And all the fertile land within that bound
To Owen Glendower: and dear coz to you
The remnant Northward lying off from Trent,
And our indentures tripartite are drawn,
Which being sealed interchangeably,
(A business that this night may execute:)
Tomorrow cousin Percy you and I
And my good Lord of Worcester will set forth
To meet your father and the Scottish power,
As is appointed us at Shrewsbury.
My father Glendower is not ready yet,
Nor shall we need his help these fourteen days,
Within that space you may have drawn together
Your tenants, friends, and neighbouring gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: A shorter time shall send me to you Lords,
And in my conduct shall your Ladies come,
From whom you now must steal and take no leave,
For there will be a world of water shed,
Upon the parting of your wives and you.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Methinks my moiety North from Burton here,
In quantity equals not one of yours,
See how this river comes me cranking in,
And cuts me from the best of all my land,
A huge half moon, a monstrous scantly out,
I will have the currant in this place damned up,
And here the smug and silver Trent shall run
In a new channel fair and evenly,
It shall not wind with such a deep indent,
To rob me of so rich a bottom here.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: Not wind it shall, it must, you see it doth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Yea, but mark howe he bears his course, and runs me
up with like advantage on the other side, gelding the opposed
continent as much as on the other side it takes from you.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Yea but a little charge will trench him here,
And on this Northside win this cape of land,
And then he runs straight and even.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I will have it so, a little charge will do it.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: I will not have it altered.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Will not you?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: No, nor you shall not.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Who shall say me nay?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: Why that will I.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Let me not understand you then, speak it in Welsh.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.l: I can speak English Lord as well as you,
For I was trained up in the English court,
Where being but young I framed to the harp
Many an English ditty lovely well,
And gave the tongue a helpful ornament,
A virtue that was never seen in you.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Marry and I am glad of it with all my heart,
I had rather be a kitten and cry mew,
